Subject; GRAVITY - Narrator starts talking that newtonian physics being a good enough analog to explain the internals of the earth...: (Deep Sigh)

Einstein showed that gravity is a curvature of space time which supercedes newton's force at a distance (mass attracts mass, while true, its workability falls completely apart when we examine the makeup of planetary dynamics and general relativity is much more elegant and accurate anyway)

The more appropriate question to ask here is how slow a clock runs at the center of the gravity well we call earth as oppossed to a clock at the surface and one in deep space.

The clock at the core (the deepest part of the gravity well, will be running much more slowly than the one on the surface or deep space) it's this slowing of time that causes one to fall faster the closer one gets to the presence of an accelerating mass like the earth.

The total depth of the gravity well is the sum of ALL of its mass. That mass is represented in various quantities of elements found on the periodic table)

That mass, within the gravity well, stratifies by density all the way down to the core. From our stratisfied atmosphere (lightest gases at the top please) and the densest stuff at the core (iron, nickle, etc.)

So if you were falling into the core of the earth unimpeded by air resistance or other matter, you'd continue to accelerate in a straight line to the core where time runs slowest. When you compare the lighter matter directly above you to the total sum of the mass creating the gravity well you can see that it would only have a fractional impact on your acceleration to the core.

As an example of GR being more fundamental than Newton for understanding gravity wells. A somewhat large body in rotation (like the Earth) will see its core rotate faster than higher layers of strata. This in spite of immense friction AND in the vaccum of space. It has to spin faster, the same way an object must fall faster in a slower time frame.

This phenomena (which newton will never help anyone understand) occurs on all large bodies in our solar system with a magnetic field (Earth, sun jupiter, saturn etc) in fact, the ferrous core spinning faster than higher levels of strata is the force behind the magnetosphere on all these bodies.

You're overcomplicating for no reason. from the start to center you take the average force and thus average acceleration which is roughly 10/2=5(at the start acceleration is 10 and at the center it's 0) and act as if it's accelerating 5 m/s^2 to center of Earth. For going from center back to surface it's exactly the same thing just in reverse, so it's going to take the same amount of time to get back from center to surface as from surface to center(you can do the calculations). So you just multiply time you get from start to center by 2, convert seconds to minutes and you get approx 38 minutes. If you want to be more precise you can take a lot of different forces for every frickin kilometer and then take the average of those +6700 different forces and just act as if only that one avg force was acting on object. The same way we calculate how much time and distance passes when accelerating - you take average velocity. Here, if force is changing( no matter at which exponent of rate), just take the average. Just so long as no one turns around and says "why haven't we built this yet?!". I've had to explain to someone that this is not pragmatic, and never will be in the conceivable future. We're talking about drilling a hole through the mantle, through the core, through everything that idles at incredible pressure and heat. We and our perceivable future selves cannot deal with that; we can't even dig more than a few km through the crust before our best equipment starts to break down. And our tunnel has to endure the internal forces of the molten core not only squeezing it, but also moving around inside while the continents are moving at the surface (albeit both at a geologic pace, cm per year; but there's no super-ancient society that built tunnels through the earth for us to ride). And the Coriolis effect makes the ride down difficult. And then you need to survive the heat and pressure during the ride, not just the equipment. And.... Okay really there's no point enumerating further. But sometimes people read sci-fi stories and think they're an authority on the subject.

42 min?! Hitch hiker's guide to the galaxy was RIGHT!! The answer to Life, The Universe, and Everything is indeed 42

M is the mass of earth. R is the radius of earth. D=3M/4πR^3 is the density of earth. m is the mass of a person which the distance between earth center is r (r<R). M1=4πDr^3/3 is the mass of the shaved earth.

∵ acceleration g=GM1/r^2=G4πDr/3=(G4πr/3)(3M/4πR^3)=GMr/R^3
F=ma= -mg= -GMmr/R^3= -kr (k is constant= -GMm/R^3)
∴ It's obviously a S.H.M.E which is second order differential equations.
sol: ∵ F=ma= -GMmr/R^3 → F=m(d^2(r)/dt^2)+(GMm/R^3)r=0 → d^2(r)/dt^2+(GM/R^3)r=0
set Z=r+ib is solution to the equations and ω^2=GM/R^3.
sub Z into equations ∵ (d^2(r+ib )/dt^2)+ω^2(r+ib)=0 → ((d^2(r)/dt^2+ω^2r)+i(d^2(y)/dt^2)+ω^2y)=0 ∴Re(Z) is solution
set Z=αe^i(ht+θ), therefore, dZ/dt=ihαe^i(ht+θ), d^2(Z)/dt^2= -h^2αe^i(ht+θ) (α, h and θ are constants)
→ -h^2αe^i(ht+θ)+ω^2αe^i(ht+θ)=0 → ω^2=h^2 → h=± ω
If h=ω
∵ Z=αe^i(ωt+θ) → Z=αcos(ωt+θ)+i sin(ωt+θ)
∴ r(t)=Re(Z)=αcos(ωt+θ)=αcos(θ)cos(ωt)-αsin(θ)sin(ωt)=Acos(ωt)-Bsin(ωt)
∵ r(0)=a=R, dr/dt=-Aωsin(ωt)-Bωcos(ωt) → dr/dt(t→0)= -Bω=0 → B=0 (initial condition)
∴ r(t)=Rcos(ωt)=Rcos(sqrt(GM/R^3)t)
If h= -ω
∵ Z=αe^i(ωt-θ) → Z=αcos(ωt-θ) i sin(ωt-θ)
∴ r(t)=Re(Z)=αcos(ωt-θ)=αcos(θ)cos(ωt)+αsin(θ)sin(ωt)=Acos(ωt)+Bsin(ωt)
∵ r(0)=a=R, dr/dt=-Aωsin(ωt)+Bωcos(ωt) → dr/dt(t→0)= Bω=0 → B=0 (initial condition)
∴ r(t)=Rcos(ωt)=Rcos(sqrt(GM/R^3)t)
Rcos(sqrt(GM/R^3)t)= -R → cos(sqrt(GM/R^3)t)= -1 → sqrt(GM/R^3)t=±π,±3π,±5π......
→ sqrt(GM/R^3)t=π (use the first positive real numbers) → 0.001238349t=π → t≒2537sec≒42min

Thanks for the video. However I do want to point out that there's an error in the equation for R(t) at 4:08. It doesn't affect the final answer it just appears that it was only written in the video incorrectly.

Within the cosine and sine terms it should be sqrt(36.36/Re) not sqrt(Re/36.36) as that makes most sense dimensionally (ie the terms inside should be dimensionless, but since Re is in m and the 36.36 is in ms^(-2), sqrt(Re/36.36) results in the dimensions of sec which does not cancel out the sec from the time t within the cosine and sine terms. Only sqrt(36.36/Re) provides the s^(-1) term required)

"That way we don't have to worry about the Coriolis force from the Earth spinning"

This is irrelevant. The Coriolis Force acts (in the rotating frame) orthogonal to the velocity vector, which is necessarily also orthogonal to the shaft drilled through the Earth. Since the motion is constrained to the shaft, this component of force is canceled by the force of constraint.

That being said, what you would need to consider is the centrifugal force, since in general this has a component along the shaft. Therefore one would expect a shaft drilled in the plane of the equator to yield a longer time than would be obtained by the calculation in the video.

If you add air resistance, you end up with a damped oscillator, with a function of oscillation proportional to the force per unit mass, and hence velocity due to the drag force. This would give you a different period, a slower one, and a terminal velocity. The drag would also be a function of pressure as the air would have the pressure of the earth crushing it. This would inevitably slow your fall in the centre. This would also lead to a 'pendulum in air' scenario where eventually you will settle at rest in the middle of the planet. So unless you're planning to jump in a vacuum  (which would kill you) you won't make it to the other side.

One problem though, I think the shaved radius concept isn't exactly right...
Say you are at a distance of "d" from the top surface of the earth,
the attraction to your right and left cancel each other no doubt,
but for a small element on the top surface of mass dm (talking derivatives here), you will be attracted upward with an acceleration "dm*G/d^2"
And for a similar element at the bottom surface by "dm*G/(2*R-d)^2"; where R is radius of the earth...
These are not equal... You will be attracted upward with a stronger pull than downward when d<R

An interesting tidbit for anyone who's taken E&M: The calculation of gravitational force as a function of distance from the center of a sphere is similar to the calculation of electric force as a function of distance from the center of a charged sphere using Gauss's law.

Electric force = test charge*electric field = k*enclosed charge*test charge/r^2.

Likewise,
Gravitational force = test mass*gravitational field = G*enclosed mass*test mass/r^2.

The calculation of enclosed mass depends on the density distribution of mass, as stated in the video.
